title: Method that Tricks Users to Perceive Attachment of PDF File as Safe File

sentences: [File Detection]<crlf>OLE/Cve-2017-0199.Gen<crlf>OLE/Cve-2018-0798.Gen<crlf>RTF/Malform-A.Gen<crlf>Exploit/Pdf.Generic<crlf>XML/Dloader<crlf>Trojan/Win.NSISInject.R491618<crlf>Trojan/Win.NSISInject.R487995<crlf>Trojan/Win.FormBook.R492664<crlf>Trojan/Win.Generic.R481309
Tagged as:Formbook, InfoStealer, LOKIBOT, malware, pdf malware, phishing

When the Excel file is run, it connects to the external network via the formula editor (EQNEDT32.EXE) vulnerability and downloads the malware. The malware strains that have been confirmed over half a month of May were infostealer such as FormBook and Lokibot. FormBook and Lokibot are malware strains that consistently ranked high in ASEC weekly statistics. It is confirmed that they are being distributed through more meticulous means.
titles: Method that Tricks Users to Perceive Attachment of PDF File as Safe File

sentences: To check the execution flow of the has been verified. However PDF, jpeg, docx, .xlsx file attached to the PDF file, the team saved the Excel attachment separately and executed it to check the process tree shown above. First, the malware (vbc.exe) in the form of NSIS (Nullsoft Scriptable Install System) is downloaded from an external URL via the formula editor (EQNEDT32.EXE) vulnerability, followed by the final malware (bokvb.exe) that is dropped and run. This file is run at the end and has been confirmed as Lokibot.

titles: Method that Tricks Users to Perceive Attachment of PDF File as Safe File

sentences: The ASEC analysis team has discovered the distribution of info-stealer malware using Attachment feature of PDF files. This attack method was discovered previously, but as the malware of this type has resurfaced and is being actively distributed, the team would like to share the information. Note that the attacker used a simple trick of using the attachments name to deceive users.

To check the execution flow of the has been verified. However PDF, jpeg, docx, .xlsx file attached to the PDF file, the team saved the Excel attachment separately and executed it to check the process tree shown above. First, the malware (vbc.exe) in the form of NSIS (Nullsoft Scriptable Install System) is downloaded from an external URL via the formula editor (EQNEDT32.EXE) vulnerability, followed by the final malware (bokvb.exe) that is dropped and run. This file is run at the end and has been confirmed as Lokibot.

The shortened URL that exists in document.xml.rels redirects to the final URL where the additional malware can be downloaded. An RTF file is downloaded from the final URL. The RTF file also adopts the same execution flow of using the formula editor vulnerability to download the NSIS malware.
AhnLabs anti-malware software detect and block the malware above using the aliases below.
Figure 6. Lokibot (bokvb.exe) that is run by malware (vbc.exe) in NSIS form
Tagged as:Formbook, InfoStealer, LOKIBOT, malware, pdf malware, phishing

When the Excel file is run, it connects to the external network via the formula editor (EQNEDT32.EXE) vulnerability and downloads the malware. The malware strains that have been confirmed over half a month of May were infostealer such as FormBook and Lokibot. FormBook and Lokibot are malware strains that consistently ranked high in ASEC weekly statistics. It is confirmed that they are being distributed through more meticulous means.
Categories:Malware Information

The file Quotation.xlsx may contain programs, macros, or viruses that could potentially harm your computer. Open the file only if you are sure it is safe. Would you like to:<crlf>Open this file<crlf>Always allow opening files of this type<crlf>Never allow opening files of this type<crlf>Quotation.xlsx file may contain malicious programs, malicious macro, or virus that may harm the PC.

It appears that the attacker wrote this message after considering the possibility that the user may realize that the file is malware if the filename is the one that is commonly used in malware distribution (e.g. Quotation.xlsx) despite the same attachment being used, and promptly block the access to Acrobat Readers open file settings.

Filename of attachment inside the PDF file of this type are created to trick users. XLSX files as well as DOCX files have been confirmed as attachment, and each file utilized malicious elements that are commonly employed in Excel and Word type malware.

The file has been verified. However PDF, jpeg, docx, .xlsx may contain programs, macros, or viruses that could potentially harm your computer. Open the file only if you are sure it is safe. Would you like to:<crlf>Open this file<crlf>Always allow opening files of this type<crlf>Never allow opening files of this type<crlf>(User-executed) file is a (normal) file, but file with PDF, jpeg, docx, xlsx extension may contain malicious program, macro, virus, etc.
titles: Method that Tricks Users to Perceive Attachment of PDF File as Safe File

sentences: Recently however, there have been attackers distributing EML to Korean users. Extreme caution is advised for users when ultimately running the attachment inside received mails.
Figure 2. When running PDF file in Korean PC environment

Upon running the PDF file attached to the e-mail, an intentionally blurred image is displayed, and a security warning message of Open file appears due to Adobe Readers default setting. This is a warning message for running the attachment of the PDF, and the filename appears directly on the message box. The sentence looks unnatural in Korean PC environment (see Figure 2), but if the user runs the PDF file in English PC environment (see Figure 3), the user can easily find out the intention of the attacker.
titles: Method that Tricks Users to Perceive Attachment of PDF File as Safe File

Method that Tricks Users to Perceive Attachment of PDF File as Safe File

sentences: The ASEC analysis team has discovered the distribution of info-stealer malware using Attachment feature of PDF files. This attack method was discovered previously, but as the malware of this type has resurfaced and is being actively distributed, the team would like to share the information. Note that the attacker used a simple trick of using the attachments name to deceive users.

The ASEC analysis team has discovered the distribution of info-stealer malware using Attachment feature of PDF files. This attack method was discovered previously, but as the malware of this type has resurfaced and is being actively distributed, the team would like to share the information. Note that the attacker used a simple trick of using the attachments name to deceive users.

The ASEC analysis team has discovered the distribution of info-stealer malware using Attachment feature of PDF files. This attack method was discovered previously, but as the malware of this type has resurfaced and is being actively distributed, the team would like to share the information. Note that the attacker used a simple trick of using the attachments name to deceive users.

It appears that the attacker wrote this message after considering the possibility that the user may realize that the file is malware if the filename is the one that is commonly used in malware distribution (e.g. Quotation.xlsx) despite the same attachment being used, and promptly block the access to Acrobat Readers open file settings.
Figure 9. Information of internal Word file saved in Acrobat Temp folder

Acrobat Reader has a feature of adding attachments to PDF files. Files with extensions such as .bin/.exe/.bat/.chm are blacklisted and cannot be attached because they are considered threats. For other files that do not exist in the default blacklist and whitelist, a message box that requires the users decision appears. The attacker exploited this aspect of the software.

Acrobat Reader has a feature of adding attachments to PDF files. Files with extensions such as .bin/.exe/.bat/.chm are blacklisted and cannot be attached because they are considered threats. For other files that do not exist in the default blacklist and whitelist, a message box that requires the users decision appears. The attacker exploited this aspect of the software.

Acrobat Reader has a feature of adding attachments to PDF files. Files with extensions such as .bin/.exe/.bat/.chm are blacklisted and cannot be attached because they are considered threats. For other files that do not exist in the default blacklist and whitelist, a message box that requires the users decision appears. The attacker exploited this aspect of the software.

Acrobat Reader has a feature of adding attachments to PDF files. Files with extensions such as .bin/.exe/.bat/.chm are blacklisted and cannot be attached because they are considered threats. For other files that do not exist in the default blacklist and whitelist, a message box that requires the users decision appears. The attacker exploited this aspect of the software.

Upon running the PDF file attached to the e-mail, an intentionally blurred image is displayed, and a security warning message of Open file appears due to Adobe Readers default setting. This is a warning message for running the attachment of the PDF, and the filename appears directly on the message box. The sentence looks unnatural in Korean PC environment (see Figure 2), but if the user runs the PDF file in English PC environment (see Figure 3), the user can easily find out the intention of the attacker.

The file attached to PDF is an Excel file with the filename: has been verified. However PDF, jpeg, docx, .xlsx, and ignoring apostrophe that comes after The file in the message box forms a natural message like below. If the user does not read the file carefully, it is likely that they will think of it as a typical security message.

The file Quotation.xlsx may contain programs, macros, or viruses that could potentially harm your computer. Open the file only if you are sure it is safe. Would you like to:<crlf>Open this file<crlf>Always allow opening files of this type<crlf>Never allow opening files of this type<crlf>Quotation.xlsx file may contain malicious programs, malicious macro, or virus that may harm the PC.

It appears that the attacker wrote this message after considering the possibility that the user may realize that the file is malware if the filename is the one that is commonly used in malware distribution (e.g. Quotation.xlsx) despite the same attachment being used, and promptly block the access to Acrobat Readers open file settings.

It appears that the attacker wrote this message after considering the possibility that the user may realize that the file is malware if the filename is the one that is commonly used in malware distribution (e.g. Quotation.xlsx) despite the same attachment being used, and promptly block the access to Acrobat Readers open file settings.

When the Excel file is run, it connects to the external network via the formula editor (EQNEDT32.EXE) vulnerability and downloads the malware. The malware strains that have been confirmed over half a month of May were infostealer such as FormBook and Lokibot. FormBook and Lokibot are malware strains that consistently ranked high in ASEC weekly statistics. It is confirmed that they are being distributed through more meticulous means.

To check the execution flow of the has been verified. However PDF, jpeg, docx, .xlsx file attached to the PDF file, the team saved the Excel attachment separately and executed it to check the process tree shown above. First, the malware (vbc.exe) in the form of NSIS (Nullsoft Scriptable Install System) is downloaded from an external URL via the formula editor (EQNEDT32.EXE) vulnerability, followed by the final malware (bokvb.exe) that is dropped and run. This file is run at the end and has been confirmed as Lokibot.

The shortened URL that exists in document.xml.rels redirects to the final URL where the additional malware can be downloaded. An RTF file is downloaded from the final URL. The RTF file also adopts the same execution flow of using the formula editor vulnerability to download the NSIS malware.

The PC environment in which the PDF file is run may not be in English, but there is also a high chance that the user may click the confirm button (Open this file (O)) without paying attention to the message box that is created when opening the PDF file. Users can prevent the attachment file from being run instantly by selecting the third radio button of the message box and selecting the option Do Not Allow of Opening of This File Type (N). Afterward, the user can check the information of the attachment again by clicking the clip-shaped tab on the tab to the left. (The default settings can be restored via Edit Default Settings Trust Manager menu.)

Afterward, the user can check the information of the attachment again by clicking the clip-shaped tab on the tab to the left. (The default settings can be restored via Edit Default Settings Trust Manager menu.)
Recently however, there have been attackers distributing EML to Korean users. Extreme caution is advised for users when ultimately running the attachment inside received mails.
